Kisik

From Peragro Tempus Wiki

These small, amphibious omnivores are among the most feared vermin in Phoria. They are active at dawn and dusk, eschewing the brightest parts of the day and darkest parts of the evening, and consequently have exceptional low-light vision and sharp hearing. Despite their generally solitary nature and diminutive size, at 30-40 cm (12 and 16 in) in length and 0.45-1.36 kg (1-3 lbs) in weight, kisik can quickly present a significant threat to an area. These beasts normally live on insects, nuts, berries, and whatever carrion they can find. However, as their population explodes, these food resources are quickly stripped clean and they move on to larger grasses and leaves, then woody plants, dead plant material, and ultimately hunting live game. While it is common to find kisik eating dirt and rocks in areas they have otherwise stripped clean it appears that they receive no actual nutrition from mineral sources. kisik which are hungry follow other living creatures. Generally this behavior is a brief, lasting only until a suitable food source is found. However, kisik which have been reduced to the level of dirt and rock eating begin to clump into groups as they follow one another, becoming swarms which can devastate crops, destroy towns, and bring down significantly larger prey. kisik prefer to hunt even much larger creatures to attacking one another- though a dead kisik will be consumed in short order. The final stages of a particularly severe outbreak of kisik sees these creatures as the dominant predator in an area briefly before the kisik's individual hunger breaks down the swarm and they begin to attack one another.

The wide diet of the kisik is made possible by a complex triple-jaw structure to their mouth. The outermost set of jaws carries thin, needle-like teeth used to catch insects or bite small rodents. These sharp teeth are particularly feared, as the mouths of kisik are unbelievably filthy, and such bites become quickly and severely infected. The second jaw has sharp, cutting teeth, used to eat meat and carrion, while the innermost jaw carries a group of crushing teeth for grinding up plants and bone. Each jaw can be opened and closed separately, presenting a formidable array of food processing options. Moreover, these jaws can be opened to about 180 degrees, allowing even the innermost set of teeth to be brought to bear against a potential food source without the others interfering.

While kisik are agile and capable climbers, with opposable thumbs and large, sticky pads on the end of each digit, they are amphibious by nature, and prefer to remain near water. Part of this is their life cycle, which begins much like frogs; as water-based eggs which hatch into tadpoles. Eggs are abandoned after being lain and incubate for three months before hatching. The immature kisik remain as tadpoles for about six months before beginning to mature. Three months later the kisik is a mature adult and can emerge from the water. Kisik remain female until their first mating, producing eggs once fertilized by a male. These virgins are exceptionally picky in their mates, seeking only the best possible mate. Should a Kisik encounter no acceptable males over the next year of their life they will simply lay their eggs producing a clutch of offspring with identical traits. Generally clutches are between 40 and 80 eggs, though clutches as large as 500 eggs have been found. Once a kisik has lain its eggs it becomes male, seeking to mate promiscuously with "females" of its species until it dies at the age of 3.
